channel.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
channel.description:
So I was thinking.... If we can witness stars exploding etc that happened 2k+ years ago NOW, then whose to say you cant go back in time?
Think about it... Another civilization a fuckload away could be looking at us with a super high powered telescope and be seeing the medieval ages, and someone even farther could be seeing the caveman time...
So basically WE CAN go back and witness time by escaping light.
If you think of earth as a projector lens, weve been projecting our history and every movement/natural disaster weve seen across the universe for years. By simply flying away from that lens faster than the speed of light, we could go back in time, or at least see what was happening, because approaching earth again would revert us.
but thats assuming you can go faster than the speed of light in order to get away from it
so ye discuss brb ima hit another one

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:21, topic:419431”]Let’s say that there was a planet in a distant galaxy, and it took 5000 years for the light reflecting off that planet to reach us, and that somehow, we had a telescope that could see what was happening on that planet (or rather, the reflections of light from that planet). Now, let’s say that they were a modern planet (industrious, etc), and let’s say that with this high power telescope we have at our disposal, we see a rape occur (an arbitrary event. It could be a robbery, mugging, whatever you like). Now, you couldn’t very well stop the crime from happening. Why? Because the event happened 5000 years ago. If you tried to send a warning to that planet, it would take 5000 years for it to reach them.

In order (according to my knowledge) for us to really influence an event like that, we would need to send that signal at 5000 times the speed of light. In that sense, you could potentially alter the past. However, although you sent the signal, and they certainly received the signal, that does not mean that they had the technology to interpret that signal.[/quote]

If we on earth ever create a telescope powerful enough to see every single detail on a distant planet, and we have a space ship that is capable of traveling faster than light, we still can’t change the past on that planet. The light that reaches us is a result of events on that planet. If for instance the planet is exactly one light year away, the rape or whatever obviously happened a year ago. If we then decide to travel to that planet, and have a telescope on board that is fixated on the target planet, all we will see is everything fast forwarding, like a videotape. When we reach the planet, we’ve arrived there in the present, 2 years after the crime.

So in one year time, we witness the events of 2 years on that other planet.

Read full topic
item.source: Going back in time/time travel in general

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

primers time travel is like that, rather than diverging timelines its like a tape, going back in time is like rewinding the tape then recording over the top, its interesting cuz this sometimes leaves remnants from other timelines that they now have no recollection of or even any way of discerning how it happened, because the end points are lost

Read full topic

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

or perhaps, when they get sent back in time they literally do just that, time goes backwards not they went back in time

I like star trek and stargate because they deal a lot with time travel, in stargate for example one episode I remember is someone wanted to go back in time to re-live the past and it sent everyone else back in time too with no recollection of the incident

Read full topic
item.source: Going back in time/time travel in general

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Anyway, if traveling back in time were possible, even any time in the future, we should see time travelers right now with us, or some time in the past, right? Unless they have a ‘prime directive’ to not interfere in past times.

That paradox has holes, though.

  1. Perhaps they can only go back to the time of the creation of the device, for some reason.
  2. Perhaps they have a temporal prime directive, as you stated (Voyager fan?)
  3. Perhaps they have come back in time, and tried to tell us, but we assumed they were mentally ill and locked them up. (Or assumed they were Gods, and worshipped them…)
  4. Perhaps it is difficult to compensate for orbits, expansion of the universe etc., so they went back in time and ended up on some far away rock that wasn’t Earth. Remember that if you were going a long way back, you’d not only have to change time but also shoot yourself some considerable distance through space.

OK, so #4 was a little sci-fi, but my point is really just that it doesn’t rule anything out just because we haven’t seen them… and also that ending up in the right place and time has surely gotta be SO FREAKIN HARD. Shame

Read full topic
item.source: Going back in time/time travel in general

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’m traveling forward in time right now!

Anyway, if traveling back in time were possible, even any time in the future, we should see time travelers right now with us, or some time in the past, right? Unless they have a ‘prime directive’ to not interfere in past times. Someone above said that someone would probably try to do that though, and that’s true, but then the good guys could just go further back in time and stop him, right? So maybe time travel is possible and people from the future are among us right now!

@the whole light traveling mirror thing, seeing old light is not going back in time any more than watching a video recording of the past is going back in time. Same difference.

Read full topic
item.source: Going back in time/time travel in general

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:32, topic:419431”][quote author=bootnecklad link=topic=521978.msg3800416#msg3800416 date=1319978978]

Fuck going back in time, you can go forwards.

This.

  1. Aquire craft that can travel at the speed of light.
  2. Venture off for a jouney of x period.
  3. Once back on Earth, everyone is older
  4. ???
  5. PROFIT

You just traveled “forward in time”. Nasty concept of the traveling being instant for the people inside the craft but people watching or observing from earth have to wait a longggg time.
[/quote]
that makes no sense, if you travelled faster then the speed of light in x direction you’d be chilling miles away from earth thne if you returned people would be older by only by the amount of time you left for like if you travelled at the speed of light for 10 years then 10 years back they’d be 20 years older but so would you[/quote]
WRONG.
So
t = t_0 / (sqrt(1-(v/c)^2))
Where t is the time for them, and t_0 is your perceived time.
That formula (along with its siblings) is also the reason that the neutrinos is a pain in the ass.

So 0.9999999934843c will make you travel one year in time, for every hour you perceive.

Read full topic
item.source: Going back in time/time travel in general

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

jme: If something move towards you, it will become blue, it has nothing to do with the distance. It is just that things farther away have a greater velocity and create the effect called: "Doppler effect ".

item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Bowser jr:

jme: Heath, size and speed makes the difference in color, not distance.

light stetches and the farther it travels the more it stretches. The farthest galaxies appear red.

Like a rainbow

edit: ofc this prob wouldn’t relate to a planet 20 lightyears away. Or stars in general. I’m not sure why I said “with our eyes” and “stars” lol. my bad

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

I don’t think anyone understood.

Light from the cave man era might still be travelling off to a very distant galaxy who might be seeing our planet from that time but that does not mean that our planet is still in the same state.

The memory will remain however the arrangement of particles that compose our planet have moved out from that phase and are in a different phase. There is no way you can travel back in time because the composition has changed, everything has been changed.

Read full topic

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

zyle1992:

In order (according to my knowledge) for us to really influence an event like that, we would need to send that signal at 5000 times the speed of light. In that sense, you could potentially alter the past. However, although you sent the signal, and they certainly received the signal, that does not mean that they had the technology to interpret that signal.

Uh, you’d still be giving it 5000 years too late, since it took 5000 years for the light of the rape to reach us in the first place.

I may be wrong, but I’m not sure we’ll ever have such powerful telescopes. Or maybe not accurately. Just with our eyes, were seeing different color stars but its only because of their distance.

Read full topic

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

Time travel back into the past is not possible.

Your memory of the past will surely exist but the configuration of the particles does not. The universe has moved into a different phase in space.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

why would it reach 5000 years after? if you can travel faster than the speed of light and you send it at that time it would get received a the current date and time of the planet, not its past. i don’t believe time travel is possible, nor is influencing the past.

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

thats an interesting idea, because technically you would infleunce the past if you coudl travel faster than the speed of light, which is obviously the theory but the question is would you? Because if you think about it what you can see is light of a distant past, whats currently happening on that planet isnt the event you can see, its an event 5000 years after waht you can see so if you sent message at 5000times the speed of light it’d arrive there exactly 5000 years after the event. If you tried warning the planning at the speed of light it would be 10,000 years after the event occured (5000 for the light to reach you and then 5000 for the warning to go back)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Let’s say that there was a planet in a distant galaxy, and it took 5000 years for the light reflecting off that planet to reach us, and that somehow, we had a telescope that could see what was happening on that planet (or rather, the reflections of light from that planet). Now, let’s say that they were a modern planet (industrious, etc), and let’s say that with this high power telescope we have at our disposal, we see a rape occur (an arbitrary event. It could be a robbery, mugging, whatever you like). Now, you couldn’t very well stop the crime from happening. Why? Because the event happened 5000 years ago. If you tried to send a warning to that planet, it would take 5000 years for it to reach them.

In order (according to my knowledge) for us to really influence an event like that, we would need to send that signal at 5000 times the speed of light. In that sense, you could potentially alter the past. However, although you sent the signal, and they certainly received the signal, that does not mean that they had the technology to interpret that signal.

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

the thing is, observing the light from the past isn’t a big deal, the real achievement is building a telescope big enough to resolve fine details of a planet hundreds of lightyears away

this is a picture of the planet orbiting the fomalhaut star, the planet is approximately the size of jupiter and the star is approx 25 lightyears away, to simply get a view of earth similar to this from 25 light years away would be a ridiculous achievement nevermind a bloody satellite type view

edit: did I mention that jupiter is 11 times the size of the earth? and here is a better picture of the fomalhaut planet

Read full topic

item.title: Going back in time/time travel in general
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

the only way I can see reverse-time travel being possible is to create a tare or fold in time with a time-machine, but that only means that you can travel back to that point and no further. I don’t think they would want to publicise such device even if they did find it possible, for one if it got into the hands of the wrong person a number of things would go wrong. for example everyone would win the lottery, mass over-population, visiting yourself in the pass creating a paradox-loop. there is too much to go wrong for not much to gain.

all it takes is 1 radical to ruin it all.

Read full topic
